meanings.def: used when showing that something is or was possible
examples: He might get there in time, but I can't be sure.
It might not be too late to save the building.
I know Vicky doesn't like the job, but I mightn't find it too bad.
The pills might have helped him, if only he'd taken them regularly.
He might say that now (= it is true that he does), but he can soon change his mind.
He might, if he chose, retire and live in luxury for the rest of his days.

meanings.def: used as the past tense of may when reporting what somebody has said
examples: He said he might come tomorrow.
Zheng said she might not stay in the city for long.

meanings.def: used to make a polite suggestion
examples: You might try calling the help desk.
I thought we might go to the zoo on Saturday.
Might I use your phone?
If I might just say something…
How might the plans be improved upon?
And who might she be?

meanings.def: used to show that you are annoyed about something that somebody could do or could have done
examples: I think you might at least offer to help!
Honestly, you might have told me!

meanings.def: used to say that you are not surprised by something
examples: I might have guessed it was you!
Her film was full of magical effects, as you might expect.

meanings.def: used to emphasize that an important point has been made
examples: ‘And where is the money coming from?’ ‘You might well ask!’
He can speak three languages.
She will try and visit tomorrow.
You must find a job.
You ought to stop smoking.
I used to smoke but I gave up two years ago.
Can I invite Mary?
Should I have invited Mary?

meanings.def: used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it
examples: If no one else wants it, we might as well give it to him.

meanings.def: used to say that there is no real difference between two things that you might do
examples: If you are going to have sugar, you may as well have a bar of chocolate.

idioms.def: used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it
examples: If no one else wants it, we might as well give it to him.
If you are going to have sugar, you may as well have a bar of chocolate.

related: if wishes were horses, beggars would/might ride
somebody could/might be forgiven for doing something
(you, etc.) may/might as well be hanged/hung for a sheep as (for) a lamb

examples: America’s military might
I pushed the rock with all my might.

meanings.def: having the power to do something gives you the right to do it
examples: Their foreign policy is based on the principle that ‘might is right’.

idioms.def: having the power to do something gives you the right to do it
examples: Their foreign policy is based on the principle that ‘might is right’.
